description: Middle French martingale, from Occitan martegalo, feminine form of martegal, an inhabitant of Martigues, which is from Latin maritima. Alternatively from Spanish alm√°rtaga.

entries.meaning: A piece of harness used on a horse to keep it from raising its head above a desired point.
(nautical) A spar, or piece of rigging that strengthens the bowsprit.
(mathematics) A stochastic process for which the conditional expectation of future values given the sequence of all prior values is equal to the current value.
examples: If a gambler plays a fair game repeatedly, his payoff over time is a martingale.

entries.meaning: A gambling strategy in which one doubles the stake after each loss.
(fencing) A strap attached to the sword handle, preventing a sword being dropped if disarmed.

verbs.description: martingale (third-person singular simple present martingales, present participle martingaling, simple past and past participle martingaled)

entries.meaning: To employ the martingale strategy in gambling.
